description: From Middle English beliken (“to simulate, feign”), equivalent to be- +‎ like.

verbs.description: belike (third-person singular simple present belikes, present participle beliking, simple past and past participle beliked)

entries.meaning: An object of affection or liking.
examples: She will always be one of my belikes.

verbs.description: belike (third-person singular simple present belikes, present participle beliking, simple past and past participle beliked)

examples: Yea," said King Arthur, " it belikes me more than any horse that I ever beheld before." " Then," quoth Queen Morgana, "consider it as a gift of reconciliation betwixt thee and me. [...]"

entries.meaning: (archaic or dialectal, Northern England) Likely, probably, perhaps, haply.
examples: Upon this he brought me a cotton bag and giving it to me, said, "Take this bag and fill it with pebbles from the beach and go forth with a company of the townsfolk to whom I will give a charge respecting thee. Do as they do and belike thou shalt gain what may further thy return voyage to thy native land."
